text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Martinair Airlines' staff dissatisfied with lack of communication beween managers and the shop floor. (p1)
- Rabobank studies possible ways of cooperation with Belgium's Belgische Kredietbank. (p1)
- Vendex's temp agency unit Vedior opens attack on rival Randstad by aiming at doubling its marketshare to 20 pct. (p1)
- Employers association VNO-NCW is to publish code of conduct on corporate employee share options schemes. (p1)
- Automation company Baan targets small- and medium-sized businesses sector. (p3)
- Publisher Reed-Elsevier says U.S. court rule against West Publishing will have hardly any effect on its legal databank Lexis-Nexis. (p3)
- Chemicals concerns DSM and Eternal Chemicals of Taiwan to build a factory in China. (p4)
- Unemployment in the Netherlands falls far more sharply in Q1 than in the year-earlier period. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Dutch state possesses some 3,700 works of art that were stolen by the Nazis in the second World War. (p2)
- Agricultural minister Jozias van Aartsen asks for EU permission to kill more piglets in effort to contain swine fever. (p1)
- Finance minister Gerrit Zalm says that Germany will endanger the EMU with its plan to revalue its gold stock. (p2)
- Dutch market for recorded music sees 1996 turnover shrink by three percent. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Junior social affairs minister Frank de Grave is to present new fiscal plan to make room for higher OAP premium scheme. (p3)
- Participation company Alpinvest's net results could rise strongly this year. (p27)
- Singapore seeks a complete open aviation agreement with the Netherlands. (p29)
- Realty investment group Rodamco buys stake in office building in Singapore. (p31)
TROUW
- Economic activities in swine fever infected areas slowly grind to a halt. (p1)
- Integrity is not a hot item with Dutch businesses, according to accountancy KPMG poll. (p9)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Food group Nutricia is preparing to unlink its Dairy & Drinks division. (p11)
- Some 1,000 workers in the Port of Rotterdam continue strikes that were started by their Amsterdam colleagues yesterday. (p13)
--Amsterdam newsdesk +31-20-504-5000
